annotation.TEXT: As mentioned in the last video, Treasure Knight and Mole Knight were tied with 4 votes each, which in turn lead me to pick randomly between the two. Before I get to the one I picked out, there's a few other things I wasn't able to get to before that I may as well show at the start of this video (I'll probably be cutting out these segments where I buy upgrades later on though, at least in the first village).

In any case, here we have Treasure Knight's stage, the Iron Whale. This is essentially the underwater stage of the game (and therefore making it groan-worthy to everyone who blindly bashes any type of water level). Even then however, a good portion of this place is mixed up with land segments that involve some pretty fun gimmicks with the Iron Whale's interior, even if some of them are somewhat underused (there's one in particular you'll see at the end that lasts for a single hallway).

There are several different armors you can switch to, with each one granting their own unique effects (with the exception of the Ornate Plate). While most of them have trade-off's in terms of their quirks - such as the Conjurer's Coat upgrading your maximum magic, but decreasing your defense - the Dynamo Mail doesn't have any real negative attachment to it (which seems to be why everyone sticks with it). The armor itself allows you to unleash a charged slash after you do two successful down thrusts, whether it be on enemies or objects.

Just to note: I actually did multiple takes of this part, which explains why Baz is suddenly in a different location on the main map (the defeat of an optional boss isn't saved until you enter and exit an actual location on the map, it seems).

Chester will sell you the Throwing Anchor for 3,000 gold in this stage. The Anchor is basically the axe sub-weapon from Castlevania. It's somewhat slow, and goes in an upwards arc before coming back down. While it's effective against some enemies in specific areas, it doesn't seem to have nearly as much horizontal distance compared to its predecessor.

Here we have Baz, the second Guest Director enemy. If any of you have played Dive Kick before (or just know about unused concept characters for the original Street Fighter), then this guy should probably look familiar to you. In any case, I actually find him to be the easiest out of all the optional bosses. He has a much more concise pattern compared to some of the others, and his desperation mode isn't nearly as annoying as Reize's fire shield.

Treasure Knight isn't nearly as unpredictable when compared to Plague Knight. Despite this, I somehow end up doing even worse against him. I know I could have essentially abused the Phase Locket all through-out this fight, but I can't help but feel a bit cheap in constantly using it on bosses that don't warrant it.
Of course one last thing would show up before I enter the stage. >>

The Forest of Phasing is the first of a few extra challenge levels on the overworld map. These stages mostly act as a way to get more treasure, while also forcing you to use some of your specific relics through tougher platforming segments than you would face in the normal stages. Here, all of the level is built around using the Phase Locket.

One final stop before moving on. Once you complete any of the main stages in this part of the map, you'll have access to a new village - one that sells new equipment and upgrades, but generally at a higher price than most of the stuff obtained from the previous village and Chester. There also happens to be an optional boss fight here, but I'll be getting to that later.

Also, his chest helper steals your gold (even if you use the Phase Locket on it, as demonstrated here). I don't think there's any way to get it back, but then again, it seems to produce a positive sound effect once you get out either way (maybe it's just because Shovel Knight himself popped out of it?).
Okay, for all the stupid mistakes I've made in this level so far, that was definitely worth it.
